attributes.title: Stock Verification
attributes.description:
·       A physical stock count was conducted on 24 April 2025 to validate the accuracy of the inventory records by cross-checking the physical stock levels with those recorded in the SAP system. This count also served to evaluate the effectiveness of the internal controls in place for managing inventory.

·       The stock verification revealed minor discrepancies between the physical count and SAP records, summarized as follows:

Ø  Bread stock showed a shortfall  of -16.5 Loaves,

Ø  Packing material had  a surplus of +572 pieces,

Ø  Utto experienced a variance of -1.33 units while other stock items had a minimal Variation.

The table below illustrates a summary of the audit findings:

Implications

Even small inconsistencies, if left unchecked, may accumulate over time, leading to stock variances and potential operational disruptions.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should continue implementing the current inventory control measures while identifying specific items with variances and which may need additional oversight or process refinement.

The branch management should also conduct a root cause analysis of the noted discrepancies, particularly for the bread shortfall and the surplus in packing materials to ensure this is addressed accordingly.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Issue: Minor variances in physical vs. SAP stock.

  • Remediation Plan:

    • Conduct variance analysis and root cause investigation.

    • Increase supervisor oversight during stocktaking.

    • Align SAP stock updates more frequently with physical verification.

value: Stock within tolerable limit but will strive to minimize the variances.

·       It seems branch stock is under control

Advice to the manager to try to minimize the variation to be zero

·        In the prior audit dated 13.03.2024, Physical stock findings were as follow:

ü  Bread stock had a shortfall of 32 loaves,

ü  White flour had a surplus of 2.2kg,

ü  Packing material had a cumulative shortfall of 397 pieces

ü  White ingredient and yeast had a minimal variation.
Previous

attributes.title: Bread weights
attributes.description:
·        We performed a weight check on the bread produced and packed at the branch to ensure that the bread sent to the market complied with the KEBS standard weights of 200g, 400g, 600g, and 800g.

·        From the analysis of bread weight, cases of underweight, overweight were noted as illustrated in the table below.

Implications.

·        Dispatching underweight products to the market exposes the company to financial and reputational risks, especially if the bread is intercepted by weight and regulatory authorities.

Although less frequent, the presence of overweight products may lead to unnecessary waste, causing cost inefficiencies and potential inventory challenges.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should ensure that the established dividing ranges are consistently followed during the production process.

·       Any potential underweight issues arise from not adhering to the FIFO model, leading to overcooling.

This should be addressed to ensure that the branch produces and sells bread within the company's specified weight limits.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Issue: High percentage of underweight products (41% in 400g, 28% in 800g).

  • Remediation Plan:

    • Maintain FIFO to prevent overcooling of bread before packing.

    • Enhance slicer maintenance to avoid mechanical causes of underweight.

    • Set up random mid-shift weight checks to ensure ongoing compliance.

value:
·       The issue of unpacked bread jam has resulted in the underweights due to overcooling.

The slight variation averaging 392g shall be rectified to be above that.
The underweight were by observed due to the slicing machine breakdown and overcooling of the bread which affect the bread weight,

·       In the prior audit, underweight were noted across all the varieties as detailed below:

400g-58%,

600g-29%,

800g-4%

·       For the period overweight were as follows,

400g-24%,

600g-4%,

800g-7%.
Previous

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
·       The objective of this test was to review the mixing chart documents, both shift-wise and summarized, for the period from 25 March 2025, to 24 April 2025.The purpose was to evaluate key production performance indicators such as Utto oil consumption, yield efficiency, remixes occurrences and the accuracy of reported figures. Key observations include:

v  Utto consumption stood at 100 %.

v  Average yield was 191.06 loaves per bag.

v  Average production was 44.48 bags per day this represent 82.38% of the set target of 54 bags.

v  Instances of remix noted were 3,294 during the audit period mainly caused by machine breakdown.

v  There was accuracy of figure transferred to cash flow for the period audited

·       The table shows the summary findings of the mixing chart

Findings

·       Daily production was in response to market demand, as the average daily production (44.48 bags) exceeded the average daily sales demand (35.63 bags) as illustrated below;

·       However, this surplus was not a result of overproduction, but rather a planned response to the needs of other branches, as a portion of the excess was transferred to support their supply requirements and as also to account for potential fluctuations in branch sales.

Implications

·       The remixes noted highlights machine reliability issues, which can disrupt production flow and reduce operational efficiency.

The shortfall against production targets may indicate capacity limitations or the impact of frequent breakdowns and possible response to low sales.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Issue: Production below target (82.38%); high remix count.

  • Remediation Plan:

    • Improve preventive maintenance to reduce machine breakdowns.

    • Coordinate with sales to forecast demand more accurately and improve planning.

attributes.title: Damages analysis.
attributes.description:
·       An analysis was carried out for the 31-day period from 25 March to 24 April 2025 to assess whether production and market damages remained within the acceptable thresholds—0.2% of total production for production damages and 0.5% of total sales for market damages.

·       The results revealed that:

Ø  Production damages amounted to 0.22% of total production, slightly exceeding the acceptable limit. This resulted in a cost impact of Kshs. 2,792.7.

Ø  Market damages stood at 0.51% of total sales, also slightly above the acceptable range with a cost impact of Kshs 5,592.93.

The table below illustrates the findings: -

NB: This analysis was exclusive of 271 pcs of oven damages.

 

Implications

·        The higher-than-acceptable damage rates suggest inefficiencies in the production process, machine issues and potential handling or packaging issues post-production.

·        Continued deviation from set damage thresholds can increase operational costs, affect profitability and indicate underlying equipment or quality control weaknesses.

Failure to control damages may also lead to increased customer complaints, product returns, or reputational damage if substandard bread reach the market.

   Damages sent to Ingredients’ Balance Analysis

Findings.

·       A verification exercise was undertaken for the period 24 March to 24 April 2025 to confirm whether all reported bread damages were either physically present or correctly transferred to the ingredient account, as per established procedures.

·       The analysis revealed a discrepancy of 94.40 kg, which translates to 236 loaves and a cost implication of Kshs. 12,508.00. This suggests that a portion of reported damages could not be accounted for physically or through system records as detailed below:

Implications

·       The unexplained variance suggests a possible gap in inventory control and/or recording errors between the physical book and the system.
attributes.recommendation:
·       A comprehensive and routine maintenance plan for all major production equipment is necessary to minimize the risk of breakdowns that contribute to bread damage.

Branch management should also strengthen end-to-end quality checks during production, packing and during market dispatch to detect potential defects early and reduce the likelihood of market damages.

·       Branch management should ensure that all bread damages are promptly and accurately recorded with proper documentation for every type of damages and any transfer to ingredients.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Issue: Production damages at 0.22% and market damages at 0.51% (above set KPIs).
  • Remediation Plan:  Enhance quality checks across all production stages and dispatch

value:
Production & market damages was high due to the remixes, and flour instability caused by less settling time due to small storage capacity of the branch.

The records shall be rechecked to point out the erros. The records from ingredients normally take long to be delivered at the branch for timely cross checking, however I shall take extra keenness in ensuring they are very accurate from my side.

We shall work on it to reduce the production and market damages to be set below company standard.

·       There might be recording error.

·       According to me the bread damages should not be more than 5kg

This will be checked and revert.
During the prior audit, it was noted that production damages were averaging at 0.24% of the production and market damages stood at 0.58% of the sales.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       An evaluation of production efficiency was conducted for the period under review to determine if the workforce was effectively utilized and meeting set productivity targets.

·       The analysis compared actual output against expected performance and examined the cost implications of any inefficiencies.

·       Key findings include:

Ø  Actual production efficiency was 4.06 bags per production worker, against the target of 4.3 bags per worker.

Ø  A total of 340 production workers were engaged, but based on output, only 321 workers were needed to meet the production achieved.

Ø  This resulted in an excess of 19 workers, incurring an additional cost of Kshs. 20,645.40.

Ø  It was also noted that frequent machine breakdowns may be contributing to reduced output and underutilization of staff.

·       The table below illustrated the findings.

Implications

The shortfall in production efficiency resulted in unnecessary labour costs increasing operational expenses without proportional output.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should review staffing levels regularly and align workforce size with actual production requirements to optimize labour costs.

It is also necessary to address recurring machine breakdowns by strengthening preventive maintenance schedules to reduce unplanned downtime and boost worker productivity.

value: ·       On production efficiency, breakdowns contributed most of the inefficiencies which mostly are beyond our control.

·       The production efficiency were unable to meet because of frequently breakdown of oven.

Which affect the low target and utilization of excess manpower.
In a prior audit dated 13.03.2025, it was noted that production efficiency was at 4.18 bags per production worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       An assessment of packing efficiency was conducted for the 31-day period from 25 March to 24 April 2025 to evaluate how effectively the branch utilized its human resources in the packing area. The target standard as per guidelines is 97 crates per packer per shift.

·       The analysis revealed that:

Ø  Actual packing efficiency achieved was 87.19 crates per packer, which is below the standard.

Ø  A total of 198 packers were hired during the review period, whereas only 178 were required to meet the actual production volume.

Ø  This resulted in an excess of 20 packers leading to an additional labor cost of Kshs. 18,240.00.

The table below illustrates the findings; -

Implications

·        Although the branch managed to pack the required volume, the efficiency fell below the set KPI resulting in overstaffing and unnecessary labour costs.

Consistently hiring more workers than necessary to meet production needs can affect overall profitability and indicate gaps in workforce planning.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should reassess the number of packers required based on actual production volumes to eliminate overstaffing and reduce labour costs.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Issue: Achieved 87.19 crates/packer vs. target 97; overstaffing cost Kshs 18,240.
  • Remediation Plan:
    • Monitor daily output and optimize staff scheduling accordingly.
    • Improve training and support for new/trainee packers.
    • Implement shift-end accountability to avoid leftover jam

value:
·       Packing efficiency was partly affected by breakdowns and also due to 3 trainee staff who are still improving their speed.

We have also been restricted from holding workers at the branch past their allocated shifts, creating another loophole for leaving jam behind.
We shall work on it manager advice to ensure to utilize the packers based on production in bag
In prior audit date 13.03.2025 the slicing efficiency was 94.55 crates per slicer
Previous

attributes.title: Mileage efficiency
attributes.description:
·       A detailed review of mileage and fuel consumption records for all delivery vehicles at the branch was conducted for the period 1 April to 24 April 2025.

·       The objective was to evaluate whether fuel usage adhered to the company’s standard consumption rates, ensuring optimal operational efficiency.

·       The review showed that fuel consumption across the fleet generally aligned with the set standards, with only minor variances as shown  below:

Implications

·       While current variances are minimal and even show fuel savings in some cases, continued monitoring is necessary to prevent potential inefficiencies from going undetected.
attributes.recommendation: The current controls are effective and should be strengthened to ensure that fuel consumption remains within the standard rates.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Issue: Fuel usage mostly within limits; minor variances noted.
  • Remediation Plan:
    • Continue routine monitoring and improve driver accountability.
    • Investigate any routes with growing variance early.

value: ·       I will maintain the controls to ensure nothing goes astray.
Noted. Controls are effective shall be maintained
In prior audit it was noted that fuel consumption was within the standard range.
Previous

attributes.title: Generator Analysis
attributes.description:
·       The generator fuel consumption was analysed for a period of 25 days (1 April to 25 April) in order to find out the fuel consumed per hour.

·       The generator had ran cumulatively for 4.19 hours with a consumption of 14.79 litres per hour according to the book records and 4.02 hours with a consumption of 13.18 litres/hour according to the tracker records as shown below;
attributes.recommendation: As the audit revealed discrepancies between the tracker and book records, a reconciliation should be conducted to ensure both records align in terms of hours and fuel consumption, ensuring accuracy and reliable data.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Issue: Discrepancy between book and tracker records.
  • Remediation Plan:
    • Recalibrate generator trackers for accuracy.

value: The calibration and tracker should be reviewed to ensure the readings displayed vs tracker records tally. Shall follow up with maintenance team.
·       Noted. Controls are effective shall be maintained
Previous

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
·       Verification of cash was done at the cash office on 24 April 2025 to confirm cash held by the cashier and whether the set cash operation standards are adhered to.

·        There were no pending I.O.U.’s

Cash counted tallied with the cash flow balance as at 24 April 2025
attributes.recommendation: The existing controls in the cash office are functioning effectively and should be maintained, with improvements made as needed.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Issue: No discrepancies noted.
  • Remediation Plan:
    • Maintain current internal controls and conduct surprise cash checks regularly.

value: Record well kept

attributes.title: Debtors’ analysis.
attributes.description:
·       A review of the debtors' balances as of April 25, 2025, was conducted to assess the presence of bad debts or outstanding balances across various routes.

·       The analysis revealed that most routes had either zero or prepaid balances, with some routes showing minimal outstanding amounts. However, the following clients and their respective balances were identified as exceptions as shown below;

Implications

·        Delayed follow-ups on these balances may negatively impact cash flow and overall financial health.

The continued accumulation of overdue balances across multiple routes could indicate inefficiencies in debt management and customer relationship management processes.
attributes.recommendation: Sales representatives should be instructed to follow up on the outstanding amounts with urgency, particularly for the accounts listed below.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Issue: Some overdue balances noted totaling Kshs. 71,682.
  • Remediation Plan:
    • Assign follow-up tasks to sales representatives for delinquent accounts.
    • Develop a monthly debtor aging report for better visibility and control.
    • Flag dormant accounts for review or closure.

value: Clerk / cashier notified of that and he shall rectify and collaborate with sales team on correcting that.
We will take follow-up with TSM and the sales rep. on it.
